sense.name: engage in a fun or recreational (childlike) activity
sense.examples: The children are playing across the street. Life is short, play hard. Let's play hide-and-seek. My dog likes to play 'keep away' with his ball.

sense.name: engage in or make moves related to competition or sport
sense.examples: They played cards far into the night. Do you want to play tennis with me tomorrow? Princeton plays Yale this weekend. The Democrats still have a couple of cards to play before November. She played a good backhand last night. The grand master played a spectacular opening in the first game of the chess tournament. They'll be playing the new catcher in tonight's game. Defense attorneys and the accused inevitably played the pity card.

sense.name: behave in a certain way; have a specific effect or outcome
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1 PLAY NP2[patient[abstract]] NOTE: compare carefully to sense 5; this sense does not refer to acting or pretending (despite example 1, of "playing a role, playing a part" which refers to being a factor, cause, or responsible party in a particular event)
sense.examples: Money is playing a big role in his decision to take the job. That boy played no part in the vandalism. I think we should play it safe. She wasn't playing fair during the custody battle. Storms play havoc with New England phone services.

sense.name: perform or transmit music
sense.examples: The band played all night long. The radio is playing my favorite song. She played some very difficult Beethoven at the recital. Can you play the guitar? Can you play my favorite record? The stereo was playing chidren's song when I arrived.

sense.name: perform/act a role, pretend
sense.examples: He usually plays a villain in films. She plays the lead in Evita. The show only played three nights before closing. Can your dog play dead? Banderas was also very good playing the innocent and helpless man.

sense.name: wager, bet
sense.examples: He used to play the ponies a lot. They played the casinos every night in Las Vegas. I'd play my money on the horse from Tennessee.

sense.name: toy, fiddle, or trifle with; act without the expected seriousness
sense.commentary: Note: this sense implies a certain lack of seriousness.
sense.examples: He plays the stockmarket a little on the side. She really knows how to play on their emotions, doesn't she? She has played with the idea of starting a dating service. Stop playing with me! That's as dangerous as playing with fire! Stop playing with your keychain! I've played with that idea for a long time.

sense.name: be interpreted or received
sense.examples: That campaign speech won't play well in Peoria.

sense.name: move freely (usually within a bounded space)
sense.examples: I think this steering wheel is playing too much. The city lights played over the still waters. The spotlights played on the politicians.

sense.name: run or operate
sense.examples: The fountains played all day.

sense.name: FISHING-exhaust by allowing to pull on the line
sense.examples: John knows how to play a hooked fish.

sense.name: PLAY ALONG-cooperate or pretend to cooperate
sense.examples: He decided to play along with the burglars for the moment. I don't know where he's going with it, but just play along for now.

sense.name: PLAY ALONG-musically accompany
sense.examples: Children love to play along on the piano and sing their favorite songs. Is it ok to play the song along with the tape?

sense.name: PLAY AROUND-work or deal with in an amateurish or casual manner
sense.examples: He plays around with investments but he never makes any money. I've been playing around with the idea of writing poetry for a while now. Will you stop playing around? We are trying to get some work done here.

sense.name: PLAY AROUND-commit adultery
sense.examples: He says that he is not merely interested in playing around with her. He plays around a lot.

sense.name: PLAY BACK-reproduce a recording as on a recorder
sense.examples: They played back the conversation to show that their client was innocent. Play back the tape you just recorded and listen carefully. She played back the incident over and over again in her head.

sense.name: PLAY DOWN-understate importance or quality of
sense.examples: A lawyer by profession, he knew he must mentally play down the danger. Helen played down her disability despite its devastating effect. She played down her influence on domestic politics.

sense.name: PLAY OFF-set into opposition or rivalry
sense.commentary: Is: PLAY OFF Note: Set as rivals often for an advantage.
sense.examples: The winners will play off against each other in the Championship Cup. Hungarian minimalism plays off against Polish expressionism. Watt and the guitarist played off of each other putting on a great performance!

sense.name: PLAY OUT-happen or develop; go from beginning to end
sense.examples: I wonder how this debate will play out. The way the conference played out last year, you have to be ready every weekend.

sense.name: PLAY UP-emphasize, highlight, or exaggerate
sense.examples: No need to play the story up. The magnitude of the event is implicit in the facts. James Plum played up his life's setbacks as if they were 'gifts...even treasures'.

sense.name: PLAY UP-meet a standard or expectation
sense.examples: Gillian Apps played up to her title, as she propelled her team to victory. He's had some weeks where he hasn't played up to his expectations or ours.

sense.name: PLAY UP-ingratiate oneself, often with insincere behavior
sense.examples: It's unbelievable how she plays up to her supervisors. The cast members so obviously played up to the camera.

sense.name: idiomatic expressions
sense.commentary: Includes: PLAY A JOKE ON PLAY A TRICK ON PLAY FALSE PLAY HOOKY PLAY IT BY EAR PLAY POSSUM

sense.name: none of the above
none of the above
